questions.text: Which among the following is also known as the anterior labial nerve in females?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anterior labial nerve is the terminal branch of the ilioinguinal nerve in females, providing sensory innervation to the labia majora.

Ilioinguinal nerve :

  • The ilioinguinal nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the lower abdominal wall.
  • The motor branches of the ilioinguinal nerve supply the transversus abdominis and the internal abdominal oblique.
  • The ilioinguinal nerve extends into the inguinal canal, where its terminal branches provide sensory innervation to the genital region.
    • In females, these terminal branches are known as the anterior labial nerve, which supplies the labia majora.
    • In males, the equivalent branches are called the anterior scrotal nerve.

Explanation of other options :

Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve (Option A): The Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve supplies the cremaster muscle and the skin of the external genitalia.

Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (Option C): The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is purely sensory and provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the thigh. 

Iliohypogastric nerve (Option D): Motor branches of the iliohypogastric nerve innervate the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles. While the cutaneous branches innervate the posterolateral gluteal and the skin of the hypogastric region.

questions.text: The inferior border of the rectus sheath posteriorly is called the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The rectus sheath is an aponeurotic tendinous sheath formed by the lateral abdominal muscles - external oblique, internal oblique and transversus abdominis.
  • The rectus sheath encloses the rectus abdominis and pyramidalis muscles.
  • The arcuate line is located midway between the umbilicus and pubic symphysis. Below this line, there is no posterior wall of the sheath, and the rectus abdominis muscle is in direct contact with the fascia transversalis.
  • Thus, the rectus sheath completely encloses the rectus abdominis muscle anteriorly, while posteriorly the sheath is incomplete and it ends inferiorly at the arcuate line.

Formation of the rectus sheath :

Above the arcuate line (Upper 3/4th of rectus abdominis):

  • The anterior wall is formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique and anterior lamellae of the internal oblique.
  • The posterior wall is formed by the posterior lamellae of the internal oblique and aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis.

Below the arcuate line (Lower 1/3rd of rectus abdominis) :

  • There is no posterior wall of the rectus sheath, and the anterior wall of the sheath consists of the aponeuroses of the external oblique, the internal oblique, and the transversus abdominis muscles.

Explanation of other options :

Falx inguinalis (Option A): Also known as the conjoint tendon, it is formed by the fusion of fibres of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles. It inserts into the pubic crest and pectineal line and reinforces the medial one-third of the posterior wall of the inguinal ligament.

Inguinal ligament (Option B): The Inguinal ligament is a modification of the external oblique aponeurosis and forms the floor of the inguinal canal.

Internal inguinal ring (Option C): The Internal (deep) inguinal ring is a defect in the fascia transversalis and acts as an inlet of the inguinal canal.

questions.text: A medical student was asked by her preceptor to palpate the margin of the superficial inguinal ring of a healthy male patient. After tracing her finger down the edge of the medial crus of the superficial inguinal ring, she felt a bony protuberance deep to the lateral edge of the spermatic cord, which she correctly identified as the :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The superficial inguinal ring is a defect in the external oblique muscle and is located above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

While palpating the lateral edge of the spermatic cord, the pubic tubercle is the bony landmark felt deep to it.

Superficial inguinal ring :

  • The superficial (external) inguinal ring is the end of the inguinal canal and is superior to the pubic tubercle.
  • It is a triangular opening in the aponeurosis of the external oblique, with its apex pointing superolateral and its base formed by the pubic crest.
  • The two remaining sides of the triangle (the medial crus and the lateral crus) are attached to the pubic symphysis and the pubic tubercle, respectively.
  • At the apex of the triangle, the two crura are held together by crossing (intercrural) fibres, which prevent further widening of the superficial ring.

questions.text: You were asked to assist in a surgical operation on a young patient to treat an ulcer in the first part of the duodenum. You would expect that the surgeon would approach the ulcer by doing an anterior abdominal wall incision in the following region:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer :

The epigastric region (C) is one of the nine quadrants of the abdomen. It contains the duodenum, part of the stomach, part of the liver, and the pancreas. This is the region that the surgeon would need to enter to reach the ulcer in the first part of the duodenum.

Quadrants of the abdomen :

  • The abdomen can be divided into nine quadrants by two vertical lines and two transverse lines.
    • The vertical lines run from the mid-clavicle to the mid-inguinal point on both right and left sides - midclavicular lines.
    • The two main transverse lines are the transpyloric plane and the transtubercular plane.
  • The nine quadrants formed by these lines are :Right hypochondriac, left hypochondriac, epigastric, right lumbar, left lumbar, umbilical, right iliac fossa, left iliac fossa and hypogastric region.

questions.text: A patient develops numbness following an emergency appendectomy. Which of the nerves is most likely injured during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The iliohypogastric nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin of the lower abdominal wall, upper hip and upper thigh. This is the region where the patient is experiencing paraesthesia, so this nerve must be injured.

Iliohypogastric nerve :

  • The iliohypogastric nerve is a branch of the lumbar plexus.
  • Motor branches of the iliohypogastric nerve innervate the transversus abdominis and the internal abdominal oblique.
  • Cutaneous branches innervate the skin of the posterolateral gluteal and hypogastric regions.
  • The iliohypogastric nerve is occasionally injured by a surgical incision in the right inguinal region, e.g. during an inguinal hernia repair, open appendicectomy or abdominal wall trocar placement.

Explanation of other options :

Genitofemoral nerve (Option A): The Genitofemoral nerve is another branch arising from the lumbar plexus. It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the anterior scrotum or labia majora and upper medial thigh. The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve may be injured during inguinal hernia repair (open or laparoscopic), leading to neuralgia.

Subcostal nerve (Option C): The subcostal nerve is the ventral primary ramus of T12. It provides sensory innervation to the anterolateral abdominal wall but in an area superior to the pubic region.

Spinal nerve (Option D): Spinal nerve is that small segment of nerve that exists once the dorsal and ventral rootlets come together, before the dorsal and ventral primary rami branch off.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman undergoes a lower transverse suprapubic incision for a cesarean section. During the incision, the obstetrician will encounter all the following layers of the abdominal wall except :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The transverse suprapubic incision (also called the Pfannenstiel incision) is made below the arcuate line. Hence, the posterior rectus sheath is not encountered during this incision.

Abdominal wall layers incised during Pfannenstiel incision (Superficial to deep) :

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia (Fatty and membranous)
  • Deep fascia
  • Anterior rectus sheath
  • Rectus abdominis muscle
  • Transversalis fascia
  • Extraperitoneal fat and parietal peritoneum

Formation of the rectus sheath :

Above the arcuate line (Upper 3/4th of rectus abdominis):

  • The anterior wall is formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique and anterior lamellae of the internal oblique.
  • The posterior wall is formed by the posterior lamellae of the internal oblique and the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis.

Below the arcuate line (Lower 1/3rd of rectus abdominis) :

  • There is no posterior wall of the rectus sheath, and the anterior wall of the sheath consists of the aponeuroses of the external oblique, the internal oblique, and the transversus abdominis muscles.

questions.text: In order to reduce a hernia, a surgeon finds it necessary to ligate an artery in the extraperitoneal connective tissue running vertically just medial to the bowel as the bowel passes through the abdominal wall. Which artery is this? :
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The inferior epigastric vessels are found in the preperitoneal fat of the abdomen. They lie just superficial to the peritoneum and form the lateral umbilical fold. Hernias may pass lateral or medial to these vessels.

The differentiation between an indirect and a direct inguinal hernia is made during surgery when the inferior epigastric vessels are identified at the medial edge of the deep internal ring:

  • An indirect hernial sac passes lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • A direct hernia is medial to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Explanation of other options :

Deep circumflex artery (Option C): The deep circumflex artery courses along the iliac crest on the inner surface of the abdominal wall. This artery is very lateral on the abdominal wall, and hernias would pass medially to this vessel.

Superficial epigastric artery (Option A), Superficial circumflex iliac artery (Option D): The superficial circumflex iliac, superficial epigastric, and superficial external pudendal arteries are all superficial arteries that arise from the femoral artery. They are all found in the superficial fascia, not in the preperitoneal fat.

choices.text: The fibres of the internal oblique muscles run downward, medially and anteriorly.
The external oblique muscle originates from the anterior surface of the 4th to 11th ribs and inserts into the iliac crest.
The superficial inguinal ring is a defect in the fascia transversalis.
Between the transversus abdominis and internal oblique lies the neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall.

questions.text: Among the following statements regarding the anterior abdominal wall, which is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The neurovascular plane of the anterior abdominal wall lies between the transversus abdominis and the internal oblique. The neurovascular plane contains the subcostal, intercostal nerves, intercostal vessels and iliohypogastric nerve.

Explanation of other options:

The fibres of internal oblique muscles run downward, medially and anteriorly (Option A): The direction of fibres of internal oblique is upward, medially and anteriorly, while the fibres of external oblique are downward, medially and anteriorly.

External oblique muscle originates from the anterior surface of the 4th to 11th ribs and inserts into the iliac crest (Option B): External oblique originates from the outer surface of 5th-12th ribs by fleshy slips and inserts into the anterior 2/3rd of the iliac crest, the linea alba, pubic crest and pubic tubercle.

  1. C) Superficial inguinal ring is a defect in fascia transversalis (Option C): Deep inguinal ring is a defect in fascia transversalis, and the superficial inguinal ring is an opening in the aponeurosis of the external oblique.

questions.text: The internal thoracic artery is sometimes surgically cut near the caudal end of the sternum and used to supply blood to a region of the heart. In these cases, maintenance of adequate blood flow to the rectus abdominis may be dependent on increased flow through which artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

If the internal thoracic artery were ligated, blood would no longer flow to the superior epigastric artery, which supplies blood to the rectus abdominis.

However, the superior epigastric artery communicates with the inferior epigastric artery, a branch of the external iliac artery. This means that blood could flow from the external iliac to the inferior epigastric, to the superior epigastric and to the rectus abdominis.

Superior epigastric artery:

  • The superior epigastric artery is a medial branch of the internal mammary artery.
  • It enters the rectus sheath by passing through the gap between the sternal and costal margins of the diaphragm.
  • The artery lies deep to the rectus abdominis muscle, resting on the posterior wall of the sheath, and ends by anastomosing with the inferior epigastric artery at the level of the umbilicus.

The superior and inferior epigastric arteries are important sources of collateral blood flow between the internal thoracic artery, the external iliac artery and the lumbar vessels when aortic blood flow is compromised.

Explanation of other options :

Superficial epigastric artery (Option A), Superficial circumflex iliac artery (Option D):  The superficial epigastric and superficial circumflex iliac arteries are two superficial branches of the femoral artery. They do not supply deep structures in the abdomen.

Umbilical artery (Option C): The distal portions of the umbilical arteries are obliterated in adults and are the medial umbilical ligaments that form the medial umbilical folds.

questions.text: The normal pattern of venous and lymphatic drainage of the superficial tissues of the anterior abdominal wall is arranged around a horizontal plane. Above that plane, drainage is in a cranial direction; below the plane, drainage is in a caudal direction. This reference plane corresponds to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Zone B represents the level of the umbilicus, and the umbilicus is an important landmark for venous and lymphatic drainage of the abdominal wall.
  • Above the umbilicus, lymphatics drain into the axillary lymph nodes, and the venous blood drains into the superior epigastric vein, which drains to the internal thoracic vein.
  • Below the umbilicus, lymphatics drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, while venous blood drains into the inferior epigastric vein and the external iliac vein.
